column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

Slight dip in supply down to 1288 cattle or 250 less than a week ago. The cheaper trend that has hit the industry in recent days played out at this sale. Export grade cattle including cows and manufacturing and crossbred steers were 20c to 40c/kg cheaper. Price falls were not quite as severe in the young cattle run, with store buyers and feeders still giving reasonable support to the better bred types. And once again domestic processors only had limited numbers of grainfed and genuine prime conditioned steers and heifers to choose from which helped keep a floor in the top end of the market. However most young cattle categories were 5c to 20c/cheaper, with secondary and off-bred types the most affected.

Domestic processors paid to 411c/kg for a highly muscled Euro heifer, down from last week’s top of 427c. Bidding above 400c was rare and this sale didn’t have the exceptional grainfed drafts of a week ago. The lead of the grainfed yearlings mostly 360c to 390c/kg. After this a rate of 310c to 360c/kg covered the general run of beef steers and heifers which showed reasonable breed type and shape, selling to feeders, restockers and processors. Any plainer or grassy heifers faced a tougher market at 250c to 310c/kg. 

Crossbred cattle were well represented in the yarding. Lighter dairy-cross types needing further feeding mostly 220c to 280c/kg, with heavier crossbreds with more fat cover from 300c to 330c/kg. Some secondary dairy shapes did sell below 200c at times.  Cow numbers dropped and so did quality. The cow market recorded the biggest price falls of 20c to 40c/kg. Heavier beef cows mostly 252c to 292c/kg. Lighter and plainer cows 220c to 250c/kg.

Market reporter: Jenny Kelly
